description: Citrix XenServer 7.0 is the free virtualization software from Citrix. It is a commercially backed implementation of the open source Xen virtualization platform. The low cost of entry makes XenServer an attractive option for small and medium businesses looking for advanced hypervisor functions (clustering, live migration, centralized management) without the large price tag associated with competing products. This latest version is designed to integrate better with Windows and provide a feature rich virtualization solution to compete with VMWare and Microsoft's Hyper-V market share.

00:19:56.390 --> 00:20:00.050
Ideally, if you know that you're gonna be
clustering in the future, instead of doing

342
00:20:00.050 --> 00:20:03.330
what we just did in the episode where
we're just treating one as a single

343
00:20:03.330 --> 00:20:10.890
server, and creating our virtual machines
all on the individual local storage.

344
00:20:10.890 --> 00:20:14.930
We would go ahead and make a connection
into the ISCSI there instead and

345
00:20:14.930 --> 00:20:16.020
create them there.

346
00:20:16.020 --> 00:20:20.170
But we do have to be careful,
because once we actually try to do that

347
00:20:20.170 --> 00:20:24.440
we can't just add in a second machine and
access the same storage device.

348
00:20:24.440 --> 00:20:27.500
If you do that two machines
accessing the same hard drive

349
00:20:27.500 --> 00:20:31.820
it can cause disruptions and that
actually break the physical disk itself.

350
00:20:31.820 --> 00:20:34.810
So that's why we don't
want to that immediately.

351
00:20:34.810 --> 00:20:38.410
So at this point we're gonna
show you how you create that and

352
00:20:38.410 --> 00:20:40.550
then we are gonna actually bring that in.

353
00:20:40.550 --> 00:20:42.640
So we're gonna make an ISCSI connection.

354
00:20:42.640 --> 00:20:44.500
We're gonna do some constrains as well.

355
00:20:44.500 --> 00:20:48.610
But at this point I've run out of time
which means we have to save that for

356
00:20:48.610 --> 00:20:53.060
the next show on configuring storage
the way that we want as well.

357
00:20:53.060 --> 00:20:56.150
>> All right, well that's okay we
do have extra time to go ahead and

358
00:20:56.150 --> 00:20:57.250
create a new episodes.

359
00:20:57.250 --> 00:20:58.520
So stay tuned ladies and

360
00:20:58.520 --> 00:21:01.960
gentlemen because we do have some
more Xen server headed your way.

361
00:21:01.960 --> 00:21:06.150
But for this show like Ronnie said, we did
run out of time, so we'll go ahead and

362
00:21:06.150 --> 00:21:07.460
see you next time here at ITProTV.

363
00:21:07.460 --> 00:21:09.420
Remember, I'm your show
host Cherokee Boose.

364
00:21:09.420 --> 00:21:10.320
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

365
00:21:10.320 --> 00:21:11.621
>> See you later.

366
00:21:13.805 --> 00:21:19.612
[MUSIC]

367
00:21:19.612 --> 00:21:20.663
>> Thank you for watching.

368
00:21:20.663 --> 00:21:22.105
IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee explain how to set up a cluster or heterogenous resource pool for redundancy. Ronnie shares best practices for configuration as he walks thru the steps.
episodes.title: Create a Cluster
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.517
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.517 --> 00:00:06.423
I'm your host.
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.423 --> 00:00:08.390
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.390 --> 00:00:11.908
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.908 --> 00:00:14.609
Welcome to your Citrix XenServer show.

6
00:00:14.609 --> 00:00:17.060
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.060 --> 00:00:18.180
If you've been following along,

8
00:00:18.180 --> 00:00:21.630
you'll notice that we've been talking
about custom configurations in creating

9
00:00:21.630 --> 00:00:24.480
virtual machines within
your XenServer environment.

10
00:00:24.480 --> 00:00:28.050
In this show, we'll be taking a look
at setting up and creating clusters.

11
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:29.660
So with us today, we have Mr.

12
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:33.600
Ronnie Wong in studios to help set us
up and walk us through this process.

13
00:00:33.600 --> 00:00:34.310
Thank you, Ronnie.

14
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:37.130
Well, thank you for
having me back as we continue on our

15
00:00:37.130 --> 00:00:41.140
little journey here to understanding
a little bit more about Citrix XenServer.

16
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:45.770
We are continuing on the process
where last episode or

17
00:00:45.770 --> 00:00:50.420
a couple of episodes ago, it's beginning
to kind of blur together about where I am.

18
00:00:50.420 --> 00:00:54.390
We really did take a look at
the idea of creating storage, right,

19
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:56.240
storage repositories.

20
00:00:56.240 --> 00:01:00.340
When we talked about the different types
of storage that we can create, and

21
00:01:00.340 --> 00:01:04.630
when we created VMs, we also created
them on what we call the local storage.

22
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:07.160
Remember that means,
on each XenServer host,

23
00:01:07.160 --> 00:01:11.460
the VMs are essentially hosted right
there inside that local storage.

24
00:01:11.460 --> 00:01:14.950
And if you think about that, that sounds
like a great idea, because well, that's

25
00:01:14.950 --> 00:01:18.121
pretty much the only storage that we had
if we only have one XenServer available.

26
00:01:18.121 --> 00:01:22.940
But if I have multiple
XenServers available to me and

27
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:26.760
I wanna be able to take advantage of,
well a couple of different things.

28
00:01:26.760 --> 00:01:30.950
One, the idea of redundancy to help me
to eliminate single points of failure.

29
00:01:30.950 --> 00:01:36.310
Two, I could also be able to access
instead of creating two different

30
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:41.240
storage locations, access a single
location in terms of storage.

31
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:45.410
Then I wanna begin to create what we
call a cluster to help us do that.

32
00:01:45.410 --> 00:01:50.022
And that means clustering two
XenServer hosts together, and

33
00:01:50.022 --> 00:01:55.354
really making them managed as one and
almost performing as one as well.

34
00:01:55.354 --> 00:01:58.390
The advantage of that, like we said,
is really about failure.

35
00:01:58.390 --> 00:02:02.360
If one fails, the other one is still
available for us and that's a good thing.

36
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:06.100
Well we can't even stress how important
that redundancy is in today's environment

37
00:02:06.100 --> 00:02:10.370
that you hear all the time trying to have
our five nines our constant of time and

38
00:02:10.370 --> 00:02:13.470
well this is a way you can go ahead and
provide that for your organization.

39
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:14.500
It really is.

40
00:02:14.500 --> 00:02:19.690
The neat thing about it, right,
is because of the way that we work today,

41
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:23.640
we start to realize that really a lot
of the slow downs that we have,

42
00:02:23.640 --> 00:02:26.550
especially when it comes
to maintaining and

43
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:30.280
monitoring systems,
is when systems go down.

44
00:02:30.280 --> 00:02:33.910
So when we start talking about
virtualization environments, right?

45
00:02:33.910 --> 00:02:36.850
We're normally not saying,
just two machines going down, what

46
00:02:36.850 --> 00:02:41.970
we're really saying is all the machines in
that virtualization environment go down.

47
00:02:41.970 --> 00:02:43.950
And that's something we
really want to prevent.

48
00:02:43.950 --> 00:02:47.140
Clustering gives us that ability to do so.

49
00:02:47.140 --> 00:02:49.860
Depending on how we cluster them together,
and

50
00:02:49.860 --> 00:02:53.110
the hardware,
the underlying hardware that we also have,

51
00:02:53.110 --> 00:02:57.690
supporting that cluster it could be
with super high performance hardware.

52
00:02:57.690 --> 00:03:00.730
And if everything is configured
the way that you want to,

53
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:05.400
the downtime is relatively
minimal when a machine goes down.

54
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:09.050
The first time that I ever experienced
this in a non-cluster environment,

55
00:03:09.050 --> 00:03:11.660
even with two different
virtualization hosts,

56
00:03:11.660 --> 00:03:16.400
using the same virtualization
technology we still had to move all of

57
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:21.070
those VMs that we are able to access off
those drives that were on local storage.

58
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:22.260
And then export them and

59
00:03:22.260 --> 00:03:26.050
move them over to the other XenServer
which still took hours for us to do.

60
00:03:26.050 --> 00:03:29.665
But it was faster than
what we had done before.

61
00:03:29.665 --> 00:03:34.024
But now we're talking about maybe we can
do this within a mere matter of minutes,

62
00:03:34.024 --> 00:03:38.127
if not almost instantaneously if you do
set up some type of configuration for

63
00:03:38.127 --> 00:03:41.163
what we call high availability
configuration as well.

64
00:03:41.163 --> 00:03:45.739
So it gives us to have ability to do so
if we have everything in place that we

65
00:03:45.739 --> 00:03:49.260
need to, so
where does this idea really begin?

66
00:03:49.260 --> 00:03:52.480
Well, it begins with
that idea of storage too.

67
00:03:52.480 --> 00:03:55.168
So, one of the shows that we did where
we would talk about the storage,

68
00:03:55.168 --> 00:03:57.180
one of the last things I said is, hey,

69
00:03:57.180 --> 00:04:01.590
we are going to connect to
a remote storage unit, right?

70
00:04:01.590 --> 00:04:05.696
So, I have an Sam target that
I've set up previously, and

71
00:04:05.696 --> 00:04:07.821
we just didn't have time
to do it on the show.

72
00:04:07.821 --> 00:04:11.536
So, it's a great place for us to pick up
right now and make sure that we understand

73
00:04:11.536 --> 00:04:15.365
how to configure that and then we'll move
into the clustering environment and then

74
00:04:15.365 --> 00:04:19.390
talk about how we connect that and why we
have to be worried about that as a well.

75
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:23.595
So let's go ahead and start right there
as we kind of pick up where we left off.

76
00:04:23.595 --> 00:04:24.521
That way I don't leave anything out and

77
00:04:24.521 --> 00:04:25.765
then we'll have a good start
to clustering as well.

78
00:04:25.765 --> 00:04:27.130
Sounds good to me.

79
00:04:27.130 --> 00:04:31.020
Okay, so we're just gonna take
the idea of Xen Xerver 01 again And

80
00:04:31.020 --> 00:04:35.200
we're gonna treat it as if it's
just a standalone environment.

81
00:04:35.200 --> 00:04:37.994
Even in a standalone
environment offloading all

82
00:04:37.994 --> 00:04:40.922
your VMs to a device that's designed for
storage,

83
00:04:40.922 --> 00:04:45.040
right, designed for high speed access,
is probably a good idea.

84
00:04:45.040 --> 00:04:49.140
Now I'm using iSCSI,
which means there are some limitations

85
00:04:49.140 --> 00:04:51.150
unless I have everything
specially configured.

86
00:04:51.150 --> 00:04:54.110
And if you go back and see that show
I talked about the very fact that it

87
00:04:54.110 --> 00:04:56.900
really does need its own dedicated switch.

88
00:04:56.900 --> 00:04:59.910
We need to make sure that we have
everything kinda set up the way that we

89
00:04:59.910 --> 00:05:01.690
want to.

90
00:05:01.690 --> 00:05:05.719
Hardware as well as software that's
accessing it, whatever it might be that

91
00:05:05.719 --> 00:05:10.000
it's designed to conform to everything
that makes iSCSI perform well.

92
00:05:10.000 --> 00:05:13.320
But in a testing environment,
it's on my regular network.

93
00:05:13.320 --> 00:05:17.990
So I'm not really looking for performance
so much as much as just to connect in.

94
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:21.760
Now when we say that we're not
here to show you how to configure

95
00:05:21.760 --> 00:05:23.980
a nice gauzy target on your own network.

96
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:27.090
Everybody that uses whatever appliance
that you use and whatever device

97
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:31.230
that you use you can set this one up
depending on those configurations.

98
00:05:31.230 --> 00:05:36.090
But once it’s done inside a XenServer,
like I said previously, the great thing is

99
00:05:36.090 --> 00:05:39.800
once it looks like storage inside
a XenServer, you treat it like storage.

100
00:05:39.800 --> 00:05:42.060
You don't have to kind of worry
about a lot of special tweaks or

101
00:05:42.060 --> 00:05:43.100
anything like that.

102
00:05:43.100 --> 00:05:44.760
It just has to be done.

103
00:05:44.760 --> 00:05:46.350
So that's what we're gonna do right now.

104
00:05:46.350 --> 00:05:49.976
We're just gonna consider XenServer 01 and
we're gonna attach it to an iSCSI

105
00:05:49.976 --> 00:05:53.920
storage appliance, so we're gonna
create a new repository to do that.

106
00:05:53.920 --> 00:05:55.110
So the easiest way for

107
00:05:55.110 --> 00:06:00.840
us to do this, is to take a look at
using this toolbar up here at the top.

108
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:02.980
And then, look at that, New Storage.

109
00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:06.060
And we'll do it the way that we were
walking through it, a little bit earlier.

110
00:06:06.060 --> 00:06:07.990
We'll click New Storage.

111
00:06:07.990 --> 00:06:13.800
From there, I'm going to select the iSCSI,
for this particular target instead.

112
00:06:13.800 --> 00:06:17.970
And now it says, hey,
it's either SCSI or channel access.

113
00:06:17.970 --> 00:06:21.740
Well, we're gonna do the iSCSI
storage is what we're going to select.

114
00:06:21.740 --> 00:06:23.010
Click Next.

115
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:25.990
From this point,
we can call it whatever we want to.

116
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:29.548
I'm gonna do ITProTVDemo and

117
00:06:29.548 --> 00:06:34.393
you can call it, let's say, storage.

118
00:06:34.393 --> 00:06:38.350
Now this is a little bit of a long
name here as you start to see that.

119
00:06:38.350 --> 00:06:40.030
I'm not so worried about it.

120
00:06:40.030 --> 00:06:42.740
Get out of that, click Next.

121
00:06:43.810 --> 00:06:44.690
I'll try to click Next.

122
00:06:45.770 --> 00:06:50.890
Now I need the IP address of where
this device will be located.

123
00:06:50.890 --> 00:06:53.190
Here is normally the default port.

124
00:06:53.190 --> 00:06:56.200
So you don't normally have to
change anything right here.

125
00:06:56.200 --> 00:07:00.920
But is iSCSI that's the 3260 is kind of
the default port number that you get.

126
00:07:00.920 --> 00:07:05.503
If you change that and make sure you note
that as well and change it here too.

127
00:07:05.503 --> 00:07:08.680
If you're gonna use CHAP
this is a great idea.

128
00:07:10.000 --> 00:07:11.044
I'm in a testing environment,

129

in a production environment
you want to use CHAP.

130
00:07:12.677 --> 00:07:16.793
Make sure you have some authentication so
that you are connecting to the right

131
00:07:16.793 --> 00:07:20.800
appliance and that you are connecting
to the right target that you want to.

132
00:07:20.800 --> 00:07:23.474
Then if everything is set
up on the other side.

133
00:07:23.474 --> 00:07:29.770
In other words if your iSCSI target is set
up, all we have to do is select scan host.

134
00:07:29.770 --> 00:07:30.990
Target host.

135
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:34.970
And in a moment once it scans the actual
target host, it will come up and

136
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:40.665
find the iSCSI target and
now notice it says select target IQN.

137
00:07:40.665 --> 00:07:43.300
Click on this drop down.

138
00:07:43.300 --> 00:07:47.310
It will give me all
the possible iSCSI storage

139
00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:50.870
that I have available to us to do, okay?

140
00:07:50.870 --> 00:07:53.690
So the great thing is I
really only setup this one.

141
00:07:53.690 --> 00:07:55.058
The one here at the very top.

142
00:07:55.058 --> 00:07:58.954
There's a lot, you see three, but
this is the one that I set up.

143
00:07:58.954 --> 00:08:01.998
And you can see where I
actually marked is as xen01.

144
00:08:01.998 --> 00:08:06.094
And here's the IP address I
selected with that, 3260.

145
00:08:06.094 --> 00:08:08.200
So that is the one I am going to select.

146
00:08:09.890 --> 00:08:12.700
So you'll notice it's not
really super difficult.

147
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:13.950
The most difficult part for

148
00:08:13.950 --> 00:08:18.040
this was really about getting
just the target set up.

149
00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:23.680
But being smart, being smarter I should
say I didn't even try to manually do that.

150
00:08:23.680 --> 00:08:25.240
I simply walked through the wizard and

151
00:08:25.240 --> 00:08:30.680
said, here's the size of the iSCSI target
I need on my storage appliance, on my SAN.

152
00:08:30.680 --> 00:08:33.610
And I walked through and
I said exactly what I needed.

153
00:08:33.610 --> 00:08:36.610
I didn't make a gigantic
iSCSI target at this point.

154
00:08:36.610 --> 00:08:40.550
And you can see now where you also have
to pick out what we call the LUN, okay?

155
00:08:40.550 --> 00:08:41.890
This is very important.

156
00:08:41.890 --> 00:08:45.330
If you have a LUN or not,
you'll actually see it here.

157
00:08:45.330 --> 00:08:51.458
So mine is a 100 gigabyte LUN that's
actually on a QNAP appliance.

158
00:08:51.458 --> 00:08:53.160
At that point, I'll click Finish.

159
00:08:54.180 --> 00:08:59.150
And now it's gonna scan on over across
my network to create this connection

160
00:08:59.150 --> 00:09:01.939
into this iSCSI here.

161
00:09:03.140 --> 00:09:07.108
Notice it says, creating this,
if there's any existing data on it,

162
00:09:07.108 --> 00:09:08.670
it's gonna wipe it clean.

163
00:09:09.850 --> 00:09:11.500
You wanna be careful, right?

164
00:09:11.500 --> 00:09:15.620
If you continue on and you go, yeah,
I know, I'll just reuse an old one.

165
00:09:15.620 --> 00:09:20.363
Make sure know what data is on that
old one before you just wipe it clean.

166
00:09:20.363 --> 00:09:25.270
Cuz if not, it's just telling you,
look, remember, it's done.

167
00:09:25.270 --> 00:09:28.610
Yeah, if you do this,
there's no recovering this.

168
00:09:28.610 --> 00:09:29.790
So make sure you do that.

169
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:31.260
And do you want to format?

170
00:09:31.260 --> 00:09:32.877
Yes, I do.

171
00:09:32.877 --> 00:09:36.790
So I know that since I created it for the
show, there shouldn't be anything on it.

172
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:41.018
Formatting makes it ready for
me to use it as a storage device.

173
00:09:41.018 --> 00:09:46.070
Ideally, it would be better if I started

174
00:09:46.070 --> 00:09:51.860
them before I set up all of the two
virtual machines that I created here,

175
00:09:51.860 --> 00:09:57.520
not on the local storage, but on this one,
on this particular device instead.

176
00:09:57.520 --> 00:10:02.230
Now you can see that
inside of XenServer01,

177
00:10:02.230 --> 00:10:05.910
it shows multiple storage devices.

178
00:10:05.910 --> 00:10:08.360
There's the local storage that
we had at the very beginning.

179
00:10:09.530 --> 00:10:14.000
There is no removable storage,
even though it says that there might be.

180
00:10:14.000 --> 00:10:17.610
There is a single DVD drive on
the machine that I'm using, and

181
00:10:17.610 --> 00:10:20.760
there is of course my
iSCSI storage appliance.

182
00:10:20.760 --> 00:10:24.200
And it's saying 4 megabytes
used out of 100 gigs.

183
00:10:25.200 --> 00:10:26.343
That'll work for right now.

184
00:10:26.343 --> 00:10:29.990
So we're not actually using
very much of it to help us out.

185
00:10:29.990 --> 00:10:35.900
If I go and take a look on the left-hand
side, I can also see of course,

186
00:10:35.900 --> 00:10:40.840
the itprotvdemo-storage here.

187
00:10:40.840 --> 00:10:47.088
Once I see that,
I can now take a look at its properties.

188
00:10:47.088 --> 00:10:49.950
And notice that I can change
its name if I want to.

189
00:10:49.950 --> 00:10:51.485
I can add in some tags.

190
00:10:51.485 --> 00:10:54.161
I'm not going to do anything
on the general properties, for

191
00:10:54.161 --> 00:10:56.427
right now cuz there's really not much for
me to do.

192
00:10:56.427 --> 00:10:58.310
If I click on Storage.

193
00:10:58.310 --> 00:11:04.140
Now you can continue to add in other
scans for your VDIs if you need to.

194
00:11:04.140 --> 00:11:05.760
So your virtual disks.

195
00:11:05.760 --> 00:11:07.910
But this is where it begins.

196
00:11:07.910 --> 00:11:11.800
Now, there is a little bit of contention
that you have to keep in mind.

24
00:01:16.890 --> 00:01:21.180
that I may remove that before it actually
may show up inside the cluster as well.

00:01:31.088 --> 00:01:36.035

00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:27.900

44
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:32.342

out of line in terms of their patches or

45
00:02:32.342 --> 00:02:32.916
number.

46
00:02:32.916 --> 00:02:37.085
If you're gonna be running
XenServer 7.0 on one,

47
00:02:37.085 --> 00:02:40.800
make sure you run 7.0
on everybody else too.

48
00:02:40.800 --> 00:02:46.519
Don't try and do 6.5 and 7 or 5,
6.2 and 7, whatever it might be.

49
00:02:46.519 --> 00:02:49.700
Make sure they're all exactly the same.

50
00:02:49.700 --> 00:02:52.640
Don't patch one and not patch the other.

51
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:55.070
If you're gonna make sure that
you're gonna keep up to date,

52
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.490
make sure you patch
them both as you do so.

53
00:02:58.550 --> 00:03:03.080
The last requirement of this is

54
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:05.170
you know you're gonna be
clustering them together,

55
00:03:05.170 --> 00:03:10.670

56
00:03:10.670 --> 00:03:14.050
And that is a key element for
them to work and

57
00:03:14.050 --> 00:03:16.770
do the things that they want to do, okay?

58
00:03:16.770 --> 00:03:20.080
Without that element, you may find out
that the synchronization of the time

59
00:03:20.080 --> 00:03:23.950
is off just enough, where it doesn't
do everything that it needs to.

60
00:03:23.950 --> 00:03:27.150
So, those are some of

61
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:29.180
You don't necessarily have to

63

64
00:03:36.200 --> 00:03:39.020
But you want the time
synchronization to be identical

65
00:03:39.020 --> 00:03:42.820

So those are all key elements and
